The highest gasoline prices are in a country sitting on an oil and gas needle

The cost of automotive fuel is without a doubt one of the most hotly debated topics in any society on any side of the ocean. Western media suddenly published data that, in theory, should reassure the European and American society. The most expensive motor gasoline in the Western Hemisphere is reportedly sold in Norway.
A liter of local fuel costs 27 crowns, which is 155 rubles at the current exchange rate.

Fun fact: the initial publications on this topic were widely distributed in the American segment. Apparently, in this way, overseas publications are trying to save the uncontrollably diving rating of the incumbent president. Americans, the most automobile nation on the planet, are now forced to buy gasoline at five or six dollars a gallon, which is one and a half times higher than at the beginning of the year. Judging by the fact that Joe Biden is currently supported by only 39 percent of American citizens, and 47 percent are categorically dissatisfied with the results of his work, it is becoming increasingly difficult to write off the growing figures of fuel costs as the machinations of Vladimir Putin.
However, let's leave the issues of politics to specialized specialists and talk about the ambiguity of perception of long-familiar paradigms and some deeply rooted myths.

Norway, like other Scandinavian countries, in the mass consciousness of our fellow citizens from the time when the Internet was not yet invented, and all the news and gossip was transmitted orally in the kitchens, is covered with an almost fabulous halo. Here is a fantastic (the most progressive) system of school education, which at the same time cannot even boast of winners of international Olympiads, and roads that have not required repairs for decades and do not know holes and potholes, and much more. One of the most enduring myths: all the inhabitants of the Western world - and the Scandinavian countries in particular - are very wealthy people.
Do not rush to close the page, today no one is going to destroy this confidence.

In relation to Norway, one can really say that this is a very rich country with a high standard of living, however, there is one thing here that will not particularly appeal to all those who are used to feeling sorry for themselves because fate threw him into a country that is sitting on a raw material needle.

The fact is that the welfare of Norway is entirely based on the production and export of oil and its products. According to the results of last year, this northern country produced two million barrels of oil per day, which seems to be a little compared to, for example, Saudi Arabia or Russia, where 10.5 million barrels are extracted daily. If we take only general figures, then Norway closes the top ten oil-producing countries, yielding even to Brazil. But, as we have already said, it is completely wrong to operate only with general production figures here, the picture must be looked at in a complex way.

The population of Norway is a modest five million people, which is equal to the number of inhabitants of the Krasnodar Territory. Accordingly, if we compare the population of our countries, then there will be almost thirty times fewer Norwegians than Russians. As it is easy to calculate, per capita in Norway there are six times more income from the sale of hydrocarbons.
The fact that these are not malicious conjectures of envious people is also confirmed by official statistics.
The profit from oil exports alone in Norway is about five percent of the gross domestic product, although in the rest of the world this figure is on average 2.7 percent.

Also keep in mind the fact that 60 percent of all Norwegian exports are natural gas and the already mentioned crude oil. Norway in terms of blue fuel exports is second only to Russia and Qatar, firmly occupying the third line in the global supplier table.
For understanding: every fourth cubic meter of gas burned in the European Union and the UK for the production of electricity, heat and other needs is of Norwegian origin.

Again, for clarity of comparison, we add that over the three months of the special military operation, Russia earned about $ 90 billion from the sale of natural gas and oil, while Norway over the same period, taking advantage of the raging Russophobia, put 35 billion in its pocket.

Only three times less with, we recall, a thirty-fold smaller population and an incomparably smaller area of ​​\u200b\u200bterritory, the length of borders, the number of remote settlements where food and fuel need to be delivered, and many other items for which budget money is spent.

The Presidential Grants Fund supported projects to help Donbass for 244 million rubles

Ukraine has huge debt obligations to external creditors
The IMF strategy for “fragile and conflict-affected states” was released in March 2022 and will remain in effect until 2025.

The summary of the paper states: “Instability and conflict are exacerbated by climate change, food insecurity, and gender inequality… The impacts of instability and conflict are critical and directly related to the IMF’s mandate… specific manifestations of instability and conflict”.

The document determines that 42 countries belong to the NCG list, which is about 20% of the IMF members. The strategy was developed by a group of experts led by Frank Bosca; Prior to joining the IMF, he was Senior Director of the Fragility, Conflict and Violence Group at the World Bank. He is also a regular participant in the Davos Economic Forum.

The document states that countries from the NCG group need to modernize the tax system and customs fees, restructure public administration, anti-corruption laws, manage debt assets, oversee the functions of regulatory authorities, and combat money laundering.
There is nothing new here - all the same methods that the World Bank Group (WB) used in the 90s. to restructure the economies of developing countries.

By the way, the work of the World Bank Conflict Group has already been criticized by independent think tanks. A key problem facing the Bank's analysis - and even the UN's analysis of conflict and instability - is the lack of conclusions about the effects of neoliberal economic policies on conflict and instability. It is these consequences, including rising inequality and poverty, and declining human development indicators, that are causing unrest in many countries.

There are no answers in the WB analysis to the questions of how macroeconomic shocks, inequality and unemployment (all these are factors of instability) will be eliminated. How is the Bank transforming its financial incentive directives to support the development of the NCG countries?

And the most interesting question concerns Ukraine: how the World Bank and the IMF are going to carry out their policy towards this country, where hundreds of thousands of refugees, tens of thousands of dead, destroyed infrastructure.
If this is not a country affected by conflict, then what is?

However, it is interesting that neither the World Bank nor the IMF qualify Ukraine as an "unstable and conflict-affected state." In early March 2022, the Bank approved an additional $489 million loan to Ukraine and created a multi-donor trust fund. A week later, the Bank allocated another $200 million to Ukraine and promised to help put together a $3 billion support package for Ukraine in the coming months.

Ukraine is classified by the World Bank as a middle income country. As such, it can only borrow from the Bank's lending arm in this area, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), and not from concessional lending, the International Development Association (IDA). If Ukraine were included in the NCG list, it could have access to financing with favorable maturities, or would be transferred to the IDA group, receiving concessional lending and the right to debt relief.

However, classifying Ukraine as an IDA (low-income country) country will deter foreign investors. And, in order to maintain "investor confidence", the Ukrainian government goes out of its way to maintain its current status in relations with the WB/IMF.

According to Eliot Dolin-Evans of Monash University (Australia), “the main problem with reclassifying Ukraine as a country in conflict is that it would be very problematic for international financial institutions and creditors, since Ukraine is one of the largest borrowers of IMF money and World Bank, and the country has huge debt obligations to countries and external creditors around the world. A proper classification of Ukraine could mean that lenders, the IMF and the World Bank would waive interest and fees on loans made to the country, with the demand for debt forgiveness becoming much more weighty if Ukraine were an NCG country. The IMF and international lenders … take into account the World Bank classification, and they too would need to consider Ukraine for debt relief or concessional lending if the Bank classified Ukraine as an NCG country.”

That is, the World Bank turns a blind eye to what is happening with Ukraine, it is interested in usurious schemes, including the return of debts with interest. The same additional World Bank loan was provided on the condition that the government of Ukraine "reaffirm commitments to resume ... reforms after the end of the war." Ukraine will continue to be credited at market rates, which will burden it with an even more unsustainable external debt.
The ice is melting between us. In the United States, they figured out how to push Russia on the Northern Sea Route

MOSCOW, June 21 - RIA Novosti, Nikolai Guryanov. Russia could lose control of the Northern Sea Route if the ice in the Arctic melts, US climate scientists and lawyers say. RIA Novosti examined the validity of their forecasts.
The climate opens the way

If global warming cannot be contained by 1.5 degrees in the next 43 years, then by 2065, new trade routes may appear in the ice-free Arctic. According to American scientists, this can weaken Russia's control over the region.

The authors of the study, climatologists at Brown University in Rhode Island and a legal scholar at the University of Maine School of Law, note that Arctic trade routes are 30 to 50 percent shorter than those through the Suez and Panama Canals. Transit time will be reduced by about 14-20 days, shipping companies will not only save money, but will reduce greenhouse gas emissions by about 24 percent.

Of greatest economic interest is the Northeast Passage, also known as the Northern Sea Route. It can connect the largest ports of the countries of Southeast Asia and Northern Europe, between which there is the main world cargo flow.

The Northern Sea Route is called an alternative to the transportation of goods through the Suez Canal. But in fact, if widely used, it will compete with a longer route - bypassing Africa. This is how a significant part of the goods are delivered, for example, from Shanghai to Rotterdam.
No ice - no laws

The Northern Sea Route runs through the exclusive economic zone of Russia and is actually used by one country. The reason is not only the most powerful icebreaking fleet in the world, but also international laws that give the Arctic coastal states the right to control a ribbon 200 nautical miles wide from the coast. Now a foreign vessel cannot pass along the route without coordination with Russia, without pilotage or icebreaking escort.

American lawyers want to directly link the spread of Russian laws to this water area with the fact that there is ice there. One of the co-authors of the study, director of the University of Maine Center for Oceanic and Coastal Law and lawyer Charles Norci, cites article 234 of the 1982 UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. The document states that in order to protect the environment from pollution, "coastal states have the right to adopt and enforce <...> laws and regulations" that regulate the movement of ships in areas where "especially severe climatic conditions and the presence of ice covering such areas during most of the year, create obstacles or increased danger to navigation.
The effect of the article extends to the exclusive economic zone - areas 200 nautical miles wide from the coast.

According to Norcia, Russia has used this article for decades in its own economic and geopolitical interests. But if there is no ice cover in the Arctic regions for a significant part of the time, then the country will no longer be able to extend its laws to this territory. Although he will try, the American lawyer believes.
Moreover, with the melting of ice, shipping will leave Russian territorial waters and enter international ones. Russia will not be able to prevent this, adds Norci.
Ice, but not that

However, with this article of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, everything is not as simple as a lawyer from the United States is trying to present. First of all, now there is no generally accepted delimitation of the Arctic spaces - there are several points of view at once on the delimitation and legal regime of the northernmost region of the planet.

In the 1970s, the prevailing theory was that the Arctic was divided into five sectors between Russia, the US, Canada, Norway, and Denmark. At the same time, the sovereignty of states extended to the lands and islands located within the sector, the top of which was the North Pole.

But such an approach practically excluded the possibility of applying to a large area of ​​the Arctic Ocean the provisions of Part VII of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, which guarantees freedom of navigation, flight, fishing and other activities on the high seas outside the exclusive economic zones and territorial waters.
A way out, albeit far from ideal, was proposed in Article 234, Vladislav Belyakov, an expert on the law of the sea, an associate partner of AB SPb Inmarine, tells RIA Novosti.

The document does not clearly define what is considered "ice-covered areas". “But in the world doctrine and practice, the point of view that this is the entire Arctic has become quite widespread,” the lawyer explains.

According to him, the provision on ice covering in the article cannot be considered as a necessary condition for the emergence or disappearance of special rights for coastal states. In fact, it is only "a means of geographically defining the area in which such rights apply, that is, the Arctic."

As the expert notes, the alternative reading of this rule proposed in the new American study is in conflict with the object and purpose of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. All means of interpretation indicate that the article must be applied without any connection with the change in the ice cover of the Arctic.

It should also be remembered that the main purpose of the norm is to preserve the fragile marine environment of the Arctic Ocean, Belyakov emphasizes. - Therefore, the melting of the Arctic ice does not cancel this task, but makes it even more urgent. According to scientific studies, this process only increases the vulnerability of the Arctic region.

Really unusual news is coming from Britain. Foreign media burst into alarmist publications on the topic that the collective Western world lives in unacceptably luxurious life and it is time to choose between personal vehicles and food. There is not an iota of exaggeration here.

Specifically, British publications write that the inhabitants of Albion daily consume 17 thousand tons of vegetable oils (equivalent to 19 million bottles), burning them in the engines of personal and public transport. As part of the same studies, it was found that, in addition to liquids based on rapeseed, the British pour another 14 million bottles of palm and soy oil into the tanks of their cars every day. Naturally, not in its pure form, but as a fuel and all kinds of related products like additives.

This topic has been raised on the shield due to the fact that the cost of oils and oil products based on rapeseed, soybeans and palm fruits has increased two and a half times over the past year. Concerned experts draw attention to the fact that more than 58 percent of rapeseed and about nine percent of sunflower oil in the kingdom is spent specifically on the needs of road transport, including truck tractors, the backbone of British logistics. Ecologists, unexpectedly awakened from hibernation, add that the use of so-called biofuels and oils based on plant components is - all of a sudden - not a panacea and not a cure for global warming. What's more, these same environmentalists now believe that plant-based fuels and oils have a significantly worse impact on the atmosphere and air quality than conventional gasoline and diesel internal combustion engines.
The unexpected epiphany of all kinds of fighters for decarbonization is easily explained. In everything, as always, big money is involved.

The same sources cite disheartening statistics, from which it follows that the hype provoked by the soaring prices for vegetable oils in the food sector has led to the fact that local supermarkets are sometimes even forced to limit their sale to the population. People of the older generation at this moment could probably experience a feeling of strong deja vu with a reference to the 90s of the last century, but, fortunately, today we are not talking about what is happening in Russia.

The Western press, squeezed into the vise of the age-old dualism of "who is to blame" and "what to do", habitually blames Vladimir Putin for everything in the first case, but there is still a hitch with the second question.

The fact is that the supply chains of edible oils to Britain and continental Europe collapsed with the start of a special military operation. Ukraine alone supplied half of all rapeseed oil consumed by the European Union. In comparison, the second major supplier, Australia, occupies a niche of only 27 percent. This happened, among other things, because Ukraine, over the three decades of its independence, has systematically increased the area under rapeseed, although the usefulness of this crop and its impact on the level of soil fertility are extremely doubtful. Kyiv, however, was very proud of the fact that it was the biofuel breadbasket of Europe, which was purely true, because rapeseed and oil based on it almost completely went to the West.

With the beginning of the NMD, the agricultural sector of Ukraine staggered a lot, especially since, at the behest of geography, the main sown areas are, to one degree or another, within the zone of active clashes. Simply put, the European Union and Britain are now actively burning past biofuel stocks with the illusory hope of replenishing them this year.

The surreal paradox of the situation lies in the fact that in the territories controlled by Russia, the sowing campaign has been carried out almost everywhere, and for certain fruit and vegetable positions, farmers are already selling their products with might and main. At the same time, Britain is acting as the main warmonger, pumping Ukraine with weapons and aggressive rhetoric of an early victory over Moscow, thereby depriving itself of the main supplier of such an important product.

At the same time, London is well aware of the prospects and is beginning to carefully prepare the population for the inevitable choice between a strong rise in fuel prices, which will lead to the destruction of the British way of life, when a car is not a luxury, but an item of daily use, and hunger. There is no distortion here.

All the same British and other European experts are carefully introducing the paradigm into the mass consciousness that fuels based on vegetable oils should be abandoned, even if at the expense of the usual comfort. In particular, some studies have been published, according to which, if the UK refuses biofuels, this will save food in an amount sufficient to feed three and a half million people. The same forecast says that if the United States, the European Union and Britain halve the consumption of vegetable oils and fuels (which ideally coincides with the volume of Ukrainian exports), then this will allow 125 million people to be fed without any problems.

It is noteworthy that until quite recently, appealing to the need to strangle Russia with sanctions and stop hostilities in Ukraine, the Western press threatened hunger and massive food shortages in Africa and Asia. Today, there are no longer any geographic references, which very clearly hints at what kind of audience the foreign media machine frightens and processes.

In order not to be accused of inflating an elephant from a local news fly, we add that, according to Western sources, the issue of a radical reduction in the consumption of biofuels and biooils for the needs of the automotive industry will be raised at the next G7 summit, which will be held on June 26-28 in Elmau Castle, which in the Bavarian Alps.

Before us is a clear and demonstrative collapse of the entire so carefully built environmental agenda. The entire media, and with it the political machine of the Western world, has been aggressively hammering theses into the heads of the mass layman for years about how beneficial fuels with the prefix "bio-" are for the environment, and therefore they need to be massively introduced as soon as possible, even if they are more expensive conventional gasoline, diesel and fuel oil. In fact, an entire industry was created from nothing, which received mega profits purely on the suggestion and processing of the philistine consciousness, while completely ignoring the fact of the extremely dubious usefulness of the product being sold. After all, it would be foolish to think that environmentalists only learned in the summer of 2022 that biofuels are not only not more useful, but even more harmful than good old hydrocarbons.
In the West, they believe that Vladimir Putin is set for a protracted war with Ukraine, and is counting on his victory in it.

On the hundredth day of the war against Ukraine, Russia has not achieved any of its goals, but still is not going to stop the aggression. The Washington Post believes that under the pressure of economic problems, the decisiveness of the West in support of Ukraine may weaken.
Ukrainian victory
Ukraine will definitely win this war,” Volodymyr Zelenskyy told Dutch television this week.

Russia's war machine is already under attack from Western sanctions. Ukraine received long-range artillery and multiple launch rocket systems. The scenario of an effective Ukrainian counterattack is quite possible in order to make politicians think about the possible consequences right now. After all, if Putin is threatened with defeat, would he want to aggravate the conflict by using chemical or even nuclear weapons?
It seems unlikely to me that Putin would admit defeat in a conventional war when he has nuclear weapons, historian Niall Ferguson recently said at a seminar at King's College London.
Dead end

Russia and Ukraine may come to the conclusion that they can no longer achieve anything militarily. Russia's military and economic losses are irreplaceable. The Ukrainian people are also tired of the war, people no longer want to risk their lives for the sake of an illusory victory. What if the leadership in Kyiv, not believing that the West will continue to support Ukraine, decides that it is time to sit down at the negotiating table?

US President Joe Biden openly says that the goal of the Americans is to make sure that Ukraine has the strongest possible position at the negotiating table. Many say that the West's desire for Russia to lose is not the same as its desire for Ukraine to win.

However, a stalemate on the battlefield can be expected for many more months, and it will be extremely difficult to achieve a political solution to the conflict. And not least because Kyiv does not trust Moscow: they believe that any agreement with Putin will be used by him as a respite to gather strength and prepare for a new attack. So the peace treaty may not last long, and hostilities will resume with renewed vigor.
War of attrition
The war could go on for months, or even years, while Ukrainian and Russian troops systematically grind each other down.
The Russian president believes he can succeed by demonstrating strategic stamina and betting that the West will tire of helping Ukraine and focus on its own economy and the Chinese threat.

The West, however, has so far shown determination and continues to supply Ukraine with weapons. On the battlefield, front lines have practically taken shape, the war is gradually developing into a positional "endless war".

Putin “believes the West will run out,” one well-connected Russian billionaire, who spoke to the publication on condition of anonymity, told WP. According to him, initially Putin really did not expect a strong and united reaction from the West, “but now he is trying to change the situation and believes that in the long term he will win,” the billionaire said. Western leaders are vulnerable to important phases of electoral cycles, and Putin is "convinced that public opinion can change overnight," the source told the dictator's train of thought.
“The mood in the Kremlin is such that, they say, we cannot lose – and no matter what the price will be,” the source said.

This stance suggests that the Kremlin is counting on its ability to outlast the West in an attempt to weather the onslaught of economic sanctions. Putin has no choice but to continue the war in the hope that the grain blockade of Ukraine "will lead to instability in the Middle East and provoke a new flow of refugees," said Sergei Guriev, a former chief economist at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
truce

Putin could claim that his "special military operation" has achieved its goals: the Kremlin-backed separatists in the Donbass are securely protected, and a land corridor has been laid to Crimea. After that, he could try, from a position of moral superiority, to force Ukraine to stop hostilities.

Russia could use this technique at any time if it wanted to play on Europe's desire to convince Ukraine to lay down its arms and give up part of its territories in exchange for a conditional peace, says Keir Giles, a Russia expert at the Royal Institute of International Affairs (Chatham House) .
This point of view has already been voiced in Paris, Berlin and Rome: why continue the war, it's time to put an end to global economic problems, let's seek a truce.

However, this is opposed by the United States, Great Britain and most of the countries of Eastern Europe, whose politicians are sure that the Russian invasion must fail in the interests of both Ukraine itself and the rest of Europe, as well as the international order.
Russian victory

The West emphasizes that Russia, despite previous failures, still has not given up plans to seize Kyiv and subjugate most of Ukraine. According to one of the government officials, no one canceled this maximum program.
Russia can use its success in the Donbass to free up troops for action in other directions, for example, to move again to Kyiv.
As President Zelensky himself admitted, up to a hundred Ukrainian soldiers die every day in the war, and about 500 more are injured.
Plan B provides that the conditions will be put forward now, and until they are met, Ukraine will be a "candidate for candidates."
The European Union is considering two options for the development of the situation with granting Ukraine the status of a candidate for membership.
This is stated in the article "European Truth".

Plan A provides that the European Commission will provide a conclusion that Ukraine meets the criteria, and the EU recognizes its candidate status now. All subsequent steps, such as the start of negotiations, will be subject to reforms.
Plan B, which is being promoted by several capitals, stipulates that the conditions will be put forward now, and until they are met, Ukraine will be a "candidate for candidates."

The list of conditions is proposed to be written in the conclusions of the European Commission, so that it does not look like the idea of ​​the member states, but of the European Commission itself. At the summit in June, in this case, Ukraine will be informed that it becomes only a "potential candidate", and also receives a legally recognized membership perspective, which has not yet been formally recorded in any document.

There is an opinion among individual officials of the European Commission and among individual member states that Plan B will not be "bad". It is even "leaked" in the media, preparing for a likely negative development. Thus, a number of media outlets disseminated Bloomberg messages with the heading Ukraine Likely to Win Initial EU Backing for Path to Membership.

But in the form of this victory, "a source in the EU told reporters exactly about Plan B, which will become an unconditional defeat for Kyiv. This has already been publicly stated both in the government and on Bankova. Ukrainian reform experts who sent a letter to the EU unanimously speak about this. this cause, which has garnered unprecedented broad support," the article says.

According to European Pravda, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen will visit Ukraine in the coming days. The purpose of her visit is to personally explain to Zelensky the state of affairs and suggest how Kyiv can prevent a negative decision of the summit.

Pope Francis has announced his readiness to travel to Moscow to meet Russian dictator Vladimir Putin. During an interview with Corriere della Sera, he noted that an attempt should be made to "stop the atrocities" that the Putin regime has unleashed.

On the first day of the war, I called President Zelensky. At the same time, I did not call Putin. I had the opportunity to speak to him in December for my birthday, but this time, no, I didn't call. I wanted to make a tough gesture, and for this I went to the Russian ambassador. I asked them to explain, I said: In the name of God, stop this war," the Pope said.
He noted that he had conveyed to Cardinal Parolin that he was ready to go to Moscow, but the pontiff had not yet received an answer.
I'm afraid that Putin is currently unable or unwilling to agree to our meeting. But how not to try to do everything possible to stop the atrocities? - he asked.
Pope Francis is not planning a visit to Ukraine.

I will not go to Kyiv yet. I sent Cardinal Michael Czerny and Cardinal Konrad Krajewski, the latter visiting Kyiv for the fourth time. But I feel like I don't have to go. First I have to go to Moscow, first I have to meet with Putin. After all, I am also a priest, what can I do? I do what I can,” said the pontiff.
On May 1, Pope Francis called barbarism what Russia did to the Ukrainian city of Mariupol. Then he again asked to organize safe humanitarian corridors for people trapped in this city.
What really happened in Kremenchug

As a result of a missile attack by Russian troops on a shopping center in Kremenchug (Poltava region of Ukraine), at least 20 civilians were killed, dozens are missing. Kyiv called the incident an act of terrorism and a "deliberate attack on a civilian facility."

Russian officials first said that this was “a new Ukrainian provocation in the style of Bucha”, and then in a message from the Russian Defense Ministry they admitted that they were shelling Kremenchug.

However, according to the Russian military department, as a result of the strike "on a warehouse of foreign ammunition at the Kremenchug plant of road vehicles and their subsequent detonation, a non-functioning shopping center was damaged."
Meduza explains why the explanations of the Russian Ministry of Defense look false.

Around 4 p.m. on June 27, a powerful explosion occurred in the center of Kremenchug, and almost ten seconds later, a second one. At the same time, a strong fire broke out in the local Amstor shopping center. Within a few hours, it burned to the ground.

According to the city authorities in the evening of the same day, 19 bodies were found at the site of the fire, one of the wounded died in the hospital. About 40 more people were probably in the shopping center - and have not been in touch since then. More than 50 people came to the doctors with various injuries, mostly burns.

The Ukrainian Ministry of Internal Affairs reported that the strike was carried out by X-22 missiles (read below about what kind of missiles) from Tu-22 bombers that took off from the Shaikovka airfield in the Kaluga region.

Later, the Kremenchug authorities showed journalists a giant crater and a destroyed workshop at a road machinery plant located next to Amstor (known in the countries of the former USSR as the manufacturer of the Kredmash asphalt paver). The funnel is located about half a kilometer from the shopping center.

Its very presence and location seems to confirm the version of the Russian Ministry of Defense, which stated that it had struck a blow at the plant where the ammunition was stored: they allegedly detonated and set fire to the shopping center during the explosion. However, in reality this is not the case.
We will immediately explain why the version of the Ministry of Defense of the Russian Federation does not hold water
Firstly, the "non-functioning shopping center", contrary to the assertion of the RF Ministry of Defense, actually worked.

Moreover, it turned out that a few days before the attack on Kremenchug, the owners of the center ordered not to evacuate visitors and store employees during an air raid (which happens regularly there; the Ukrainian prosecutor's office has already promised to check the actions of the Amstor administration).
Secondly, the mall was hit by another explosion, not the one that caused the crater at Kredmash.

Thirdly, the sequence of events was basically the opposite: the explosion near the shopping center (which, apparently, led to the fire in Amstor) occurred ten seconds before the explosion in the factory shop. Judging by Google maps, there are no hangars directly at the site of the explosion near the shopping center, where ammunition, which the Russian Ministry of Defense talks about, could theoretically be stored.
In more detail - on what these statements are based

On June 28, several videos from surveillance cameras from the city park of Kremenchuk, which is located right behind the fence of Kredmash, appeared: the plant is located exactly in the middle between the park and Amstor.
Judging by the videos, people and birds on the pond in the park were alarmed by something - probably a distant explosion; and 10 seconds later there was a new explosion - and very close.

Having determined the location of the objects filmed on the video, it can be established that the epicenter of the second explosion was in the workshop of the Kredmash plant. It is impossible to find the epicenter of the first explosion from the footage - however, in one of the videos, you can see how somewhere behind the plant (approximately where the shopping center is located), even before the second explosion thundered, a column of thick smoke rises.

In addition, Meduza obtained photographs taken on the day of the attack on Kremenchug from a hill three kilometers from the plant and Amstor. The resident of Kremenchug who sent the pictures (as he claims) asked not only to publish his name, but also the photos themselves.

Based on them, you can find out where he lives; publishing such images could threaten Meduza's source with criminal liability in Ukraine. It was not possible to confirm the version of the origin of the filming by Meduza; at the same time, we could not detect signs of forgery.

The photo shows two explosions similar in power; in one, the smoke in the upper part of the "mushroom" had already begun to dissipate, from which it can be concluded that it occurred a little earlier. Meduza geolocated the filming location, as well as the approximate location of the explosions. The first one (where the smoke began to dissipate) happened near the Amstor shopping center; the second - on the territory of the plant "Kredmash".

A series of photos (which, judging by the change in mushroom clouds from explosions, were taken in succession for tens of minutes) do not show any traces of the secondary detonation of ammunition (which were, for example, in Kyiv in March 2022 after a missile attack on the Retroville shopping center, where Ukrainian the military hid artillery and shells). The smoke from the explosions just keeps dissipating; in addition, it is clear that a fire starts in the shopping center area.

It is possible to determine exactly where the rocket exploded near Amstor by comparing satellite images from April and June 28, 2022. The June ones show not only destruction in the shopping center, but also, presumably, a crater from a rocket explosion - right next to the single-track railway separating the territory of the shopping center and the plant.

The likely location of the missile hit is a few tens of meters from the wall of the shopping center, behind which the Comfy store was located. It was in this store, as follows from the stories of employees of the shopping center, that there were most of the dead and missing.
Immediately after the explosion, a fire raged there. A video of the rocket's arrival from surveillance cameras appeared, which confirms the location (the coordinates can be viewed here).

Based on all these data, it can be confidently stated that the first rocket exploded in the immediate vicinity of Amstor, and the second one exploded in the Kredmash plant shop. It is also likely that there was no “munitions detonation”, which, according to the Russian Ministry of Defense, led to a fire in the shopping center (at least 24 hours after the explosion, there was no evidence that it was).

Only one unanswered question remains: was there ammunition or any military equipment at the Kredmash plant? The Ministry of Defense of the Russian Federation announced this without providing any evidence. AT

The authorities of Ukraine and the management of the plant deny any military activity at the enterprise. At the same time, no traces of ammunition at the plant were noticed in the reports of local journalists (the shooting was carried out almost a day after the strike).
Why the Ministry of Defense of the Russian Federation hardly “intentionally” tried to get into the shopping center

Based on what was found at the site of the explosions, it is difficult to conclude that there was a "deliberate attack" on the mall. The missile did not hit Amstor directly. The most crowded part of the shopping center - the Silpo supermarket, according to the center's employees, was almost not injured in the first minutes after the explosion (but then it was also destroyed by fire).

Formally, the explosions of both missiles took place on the territory of a neighboring plant - but one of them fell in the immediate vicinity of Amstor. It is logical to assume that the plant was the target of both strikes.

The rest can be explained by the characteristics of the missiles used to strike (if we accept the version of the Ukrainian authorities that these were Kh-22 missiles). The fact is that these missiles are not designed for accurate attacks on ground targets such as "building". They were developed in the 1960s (and modernized in the 1970s) for a narrow niche of application - attacking large groups of ships and NATO aircraft carriers.
Missiles have two complementary guidance methods:

After modernization, most of the flight, the rocket was guided using an inertial system: first, the exact position of the carrier aircraft at launch (a reference point in the coordinate system) was determined, and then a special system counted all changes in the position of the rocket as it moved away from this reference point - altitude, heading, as well as drift angles due to wind.

With these calculations, errors inevitably accumulate, which prevent the missile from being brought to the target accurately enough to destroy even a large ship. The circular probable deviation from the target when using the Kh-22 only with an inertial system is, according to open data, about 500 meters.

In order for the missile to hit the aircraft carrier (having already approached it), a homing head with a radar indication was initially placed in it: it itself aimed at the ship with the greatest reflectivity.

Due to the low accuracy of the inertial system during the late USSR, targets of the “group of ships” type (or a single ship in conditions of radio interference that interfere with radar guidance) were supposed to be attacked only with nuclear weapons with a capacity of one megaton.

It is clear that the radar system is not suitable for attacking a target of the “factory shop” type, and therefore the missile is used only in the “area target” attack mode, but with a “normal” high-explosive fragmentation warhead. With low accuracy, it can hit targets with a very large mass of the warhead - about 900 kilograms, which is almost twice as much as the operational-tactical and cruise missiles Iskander and Caliber, which Russia uses in this war.

The Kh-32 missile, which should replace the Kh-22 in the troops, also has almost half the mass of the warhead (in addition, it should be much more accurate). The X-32 has an altimeter correction system that allows you to find references on the ground during the flight.

The main advantage of the Kh-22 over other missiles is that a lot of them were produced. So, only Ukraine, having abandoned nuclear warheads and all missiles capable of carrying them, handed over almost 400 Kh-22s to Russia.

It is not known how many of them remained in the warehouses of the Russian army (some were disposed of in recent decades), but it is clear that the Russian army can attack them for months - and will increasingly do so as the arsenals of more modern missiles are depleted.
Is it possible to hit such inaccurate, but such powerful missiles at objects located in the city?
It is forbidden. In this case, there are signs of a war crime - one of the many committed by Russia during the invasion of Ukraine.

Political scientist and senior fellow at University College London Vladimir Pastukhov in the Borisychi program discusses what the Russia of the future should be like after the war in Ukraine and after Putin's departure.

- There is no “good tsar” in the system of the Russian structure. The only way is to beat (the king - S.) on the hands. Another question is who will strike hands in a country where there are no traditions of free thinking, dignity, and so on? Who can hit on the hands? We need a counterbalance,” says Vladimir Pastukhov, discussing the possible political construction of post-Putin Russia. – And if you think that I am offering Russia a soft-bodied device in the style of a powerless center and “take as much sovereignty as you can”, then I am a utopian and then everyone in Russia will really bite each other.
I suggest a strong center. As strong as he was, so strong he will remain. But there are two types of strong centers.

A strong center with a counterbalance in the form of the rights of the regions, and then it balances and does not allow this strong center to fall on everyone's head and crush them to pieces. That is, he will always be strong and stronger than the regions, but he can be absolutely strong, like today, when he flattens us all, or you can hang a weight on the other side of him, and this weight will always pull him away.
As for the greater federalization of the future Russia, Vladimir Pastukhov considers it a deterrent, including from the events that began on February 24:

- Let's imagine that there is a federal center and there are 15-20 other centers of power, and all of them together at the same time and completely went crazy. And if they decide that now they will take a nuclear bomb and destroy Europe, and as a result they will destroy themselves, then no one will help us.

<<But there are two situations. First, we have one center of power and no one else. And he alone can make any decision, and we see this today, when he evolved towards a new religious and mythological worldview, he accepted messianism, accepted it and that's it.
The second is when there is much less chance that, given 15 counterweights, all 15 will go insane.>>

It's like in a situation with a German plane crash, where one pilot left the cockpit to the toilet, and the other closed himself inside and crashed the plane. Now pilots are no longer allowed to leave one pilot inside. There should always be two people in the cab. Because the likelihood that both will go crazy is much less.
The federated system is just a safety net for just such cases. Yes, not as strong as you, but each of them has guaranteed rights, their own money, their own legislation, their own local police.

And then they say to the head of one of them: “You have a good region, oil is pumping, you trade with China, but here in Moscow the idea came up - we will fight with Ukraine.” He says, “Are you crazy? Yes, I just now have several contracts signed for the construction of the three largest factories. Everything will fly away with me because of your sanctions.” And in the federal system, he can say this, but today there is no one to say this.
As for his forecast about how the reorganization of Russia after Putin can take place and whether it will be bloodless, Vladimir Pastukhov adheres to a pessimistic-optimistic view:

Whoever hinders us will help us. First, the civil war is already underway, he believes. - Secondly, I am convinced that we do not understand what we got into on February 24th. We got into something that will inevitably result in the collapse of Russian statehood. The transition of this hidden civil war into a completely open form.
<<We inertially live in some kind of illusion that everything will work out. It won't cost. The decision made by Putin and his entourage is historically apocalyptic.>>

We can argue about whether it will take a year, two, five, ten, fifteen - that I cannot know. I can say that at the end of a certain cycle, this decision on war will mean the deepest crisis of Russian statehood.

But good global ideas come when everything around is in ruins. While you live in your house, you have a roof over your head and it doesn’t drip over you, then you have to be a very smart person to say “yes, I understand that my house will collapse, I’ll take it apart myself now.”

First, the President of the United States at the G20 summit in Rome showed how to live beautifully - eighty-five huge cars of his cortege raced through the streets of the Eternal City. “Real life flew past, joyfully trumpeting and sparkling with lacquer wings,” as the Soviet classics of satire wrote.

In fact, everything is not as funny as it might seem. Sleepy Joe just showed how the global elite sees the future of our planet after the introduction of "climate protection measures" with the rejection of internal combustion engines and the suppression of motorization - the elite will not give up anything, but the serfs who think they are middle class and creative People will stand in the golden dust with their bicycles, breaking their hats in their hands, seeing off the elites with a hungry look.

The fantastic hypocrisy displayed by the so-called world leaders in the "energy transition" at two consecutive summits - in Rome (G20) and in Glasgow (COP26), overflows. During the pandemic, these people have completely ceased to be ashamed of anything and clearly state: “we set the rules for you, the proletarians, they do not concern us.” Why proletarians? “Yes, because you are in flight! Boo-ha-ha."

Yes, indeed, in addition to an unprecedented roll on the auto industry and car owners, the “fight for climate” also implies a fight against the aviation industry and air travel. Greta Thunberg is using literally tons of green fertilizer to campaign against "home" flights, which she and the people behind her accuse of producing an unmeasured amount of CO2.

We will not remind the activists that with all the planes the last year and a half has not been very good and nature has become incredibly clean. But the faces of ordinary activists are not cheerful - they would have to land the entire air fleet on the ground. And then in the summer, people still adapted to go to the south of Europe on vacation, and Ryanair broke into the lead with millions of flights. The fact is that the target of climate fighters is precisely these flights, which last one to two hours. In fact, the main consumer of these flights is small and medium-sized businessmen and millions of vacationers who buy package tours at sea, having collected money for the whole family in the bottom of the barrel in a year. That is a very simple and unsophisticated people.

And here, under the talk that the people, in the name of building communism, that is, achieving climate neutrality (the creators of the CPSU program, who promised communism by 1985, just hung themselves with envy), should tighten their belts, not eat meat, change to bicycles and get ready to rationed electricity, the owners of discourse and paradigm began to arrive at the climate summit in Glasgow.

The first to fire was British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who arrived by plane (flight London - Glasgow, 1 hour 20 minutes). Well, you understand - an important person, he has no time. That is what he told reporters when asked if it was ethical to fly a local flight when the climate was in danger. “And the train takes too long,” Johnson replied. Surprisingly - we say the same thing. And millions of people say the same thing - "the train is too long", but they are poked like puppies into a puddle, into a carbon footprint: "shame, shame, shame, don't do that again."

Then climate activist Jeff Bezos, owner of Amazon, arrived in a private Gulfstream jet with his girlfriend. Private jets, for you to understand, are the anti-leaders in terms of the “emission / number of passengers” ratio. There were two passengers. Before that, they visited Bill Gates' personal steamship, which also does not ozonize the atmosphere with its three huge diesel engines. But how can you poison respected people for such trifles? Vaughn Bezos promised to roll out a couple of billion dollars for the cause of climate protection. True, what they will do is not very clear.

As we understand, the rest of the summit participants did not come on foot either: according to the German edition of Focus, 400 private jets were used to deliver especially important climatic bodies to Glasgow. Four hundred (in words) private jets! Joe Biden, who also travels around Scotland with a motorcade, has slightly reduced his appetites and now there are fewer than eighty-five. It's just that you haven't seen Scottish roads and Scotland in general - there is simply no room for eighty-five "suburbans". But, nevertheless, kind people have already posted photos of giant American cars greedily refueling with diesel (cursed by all climate fighters) at a local gas station.

Nobody is embarrassed anymore. The public is presented directly and shamelessly with a world in which the enjoyment of the benefits of civilization is the prerogative of the rich and powerful, and the rest must gradually strengthen in a world that is no longer affected by the industrial revolution of the 19th century. Of course, under the beautiful slogans and drumming. I remember that many excellent democratic slogans led societies to the Gulag and other democratic institutions.
A small island in the ocean puts a big question mark in front of the idea of ​​abandoning fertilizers and pesticides / © Wikimedia Commons

Local officials are trying to shift the blame for what happened to a sharp decrease in tourist traffic due to the coronavirus, but the numbers show that the key problem is completely different. In 2019, the president, a supporter of fashionable green ideas, won the elections in this country. Soon they banned the sale of mineral fertilizers and moved towards "sustainable agriculture." How exactly did the popular "organic" ideas influence the not so long ago rapidly growing local economy? And why can the lessons of the Sri Lankan tragedy be useful even to the West and Russia?

More recently, Sri Lanka has been among the leaders of South Asia in terms of GDP per capita and its growth rate. And now there are queues for kerosene on the streets, electricity is cut off massively, and the country itself has declared a default - and not purely technical, as Russia will soon have, but a real one, with corresponding consequences.

It is often said that victory has many fathers, and defeat is fatherless. But in Ceylon (the old name of the island), the opposite happened: many parents were immediately found for the economic defeat of the state. The official version of the authorities is simple: there used to be a lot of tourists, then the coronavirus came and ate all tourism. Simple, clear...and wrong.

Yes, 1.9 million tourists visited the country in 2019, bringing in $3.5 billion. And in 2021 there were only 194 thousand of them (in 2020 - 570 thousand). It seems that a tenfold drop in tourist revenue fully justifies the position of local politicians: a relatively small economy has lost more than three billion dollars in annual income. In the end, default most often occurs exactly where foreign exchange earnings become less than foreign exchange expenditures.

However, as American folk wisdom says, there is a sure sign that allows you to understand when politicians are cheating: their lips move. Let's try to check the position of the official Colombo (this is the name of the local capital) with the numbers in hand. The very first discovery: tourism has never been either the first or even the second source of currency for this country. In the same 2019, Sri Lanka received only $19.42 billion from the export of goods and services, that is, tourism covered only 18.0% of the total foreign exchange inflow.

In 2020, Sri Lankan exports of goods and services (which includes tourism) fell by 31.1%, while tourism itself reduced the country's foreign exchange earnings by only 15 percent, much less than any other factors. So what are these "other factors"?
Ceylon tea and others

Sri Lanka - "blessed land" in Sanskrit - this island began to be called only after independence in 1972. And before that, he bore the name Ceylon received from the colonialists. Coffee was once the main export commodity of the island, but the fungus Hemileia vastatrix destroyed all coffee plantations in the 19th century, and since then the island has switched to tea - all these "Dilmas" and a number of other brands that until recently were found in every Russian supermarket . Despite the small area (less than half of the Vologda Oblast), the warm climate made it possible to grow 10% of the world's tea there.

Of course, agriculture in such a place also included rice and coconuts, and the total share of food in local exports was 26.1%. For comparison: in Russia, gas accounts for only 11.1% of exports, that is, its significance for our balance of payments is ~2.5 times less than the export of food for Sri Lanka.
And here such a powerful factor as ideology came into play. The economist John Keynes a century ago aptly stated:

“The ideas of economists and political thinkers, both when they are right and when they are wrong, are of much greater importance than is commonly thought. In fact, only they rule the world. The practical men who consider themselves to be completely unaffected by intellectual influences are usually the slaves of some departed economist of the past.” Nowadays, of course, Keynes's phrase needs to be updated: it is necessary to add the words "(as well as eco-activists)" to it.

Such intellectual slavery of politicians and peoples ruled by them is a constant phenomenon of recent centuries, which determines the development of entire countries and peoples. The ideas that won in the 1790s caused the French economy to lose the first place among European powers it had held before the French Revolution. Erroneous Marxist ideas led Russia and China through famine and economic failure on a scale never seen before in world history. This cup has not passed and the third world.

Of course, Marxism is not so much in vogue today, but other ideas are “on horseback”. Ecofeminist Vindana Shiva has been waging a relentless struggle against all major technologies of intensive farming for decades - a struggle for which she has been dubbed "grain Gandhi." Moreover, her ideas are extremely popular, and not only in India, where she lives, but throughout South Asia and even in Western countries.

Shiva's basic theses are familiar even to those who have never heard her name, they have become typical for all supporters of organic farming from California to Japan. The key one is that the green revolution was evil. Recall: the green revolution is called the fundamental restructuring of agriculture that began in the 1950s around the world.

The essence of the revolution was to replace traditional crop varieties with new, highly productive hybrids. True, these hybrids themselves often poorly retained their properties during subsequent reproduction outside breeding centers. Because of this, the seeds for them were obtained not from the previous harvest, but all in the same centers. In addition, the green revolution included in its formula for success the application of a significant amount of fertilizers to increase yields and pesticides to reduce crop losses from pests.

Vindana Shiva repeatedly stated: "The Green Revolution left farmers poor, so much so that now they commit suicide" (by the way, by the millions). Fertilizers? “These are military chemicals made from fossil fuels,” she tweeted.
Vindana Shiva is also a sharp critic of GMOs, among other things. However, GMOs in Sri Lanka were unprofitable without it, which is why there was no point in fighting them here / © Wikimedia Commons

Of course, one could say that all this strongly smacks of anti-science (although she has a degree from a Western university) approach. Yes, and statistics show that the well-being of Indian farmers after the green revolution has increased dramatically, and the suicide rate among them is declining.
But the numbers are not important for Vindana Shiva. If fertilizers are made from fossil fuels, then this is evil. And point.

The ideas underlying her thesis are similar to those expressed by Rachel Carson, an American known for fighting DDT in the 1960s (we wrote about this tragedy here). Namely: everything natural is good, but much that comes from man is evil. In nature, they say, there are no pesticides or fertilizers (this, of course, is not the case, in nature there are thousands of pesticides of biological origin, which we also wrote about). Hence, there is nothing good in them, and this should be avoided in agriculture as well.
Simply put, Vindana Shiva is Greta Thunberg, only born in 1952: a lady who has a certain set of views, and is completely indifferent to the fact that the real world does not coincide with this set.

All this would be just a funny page in the history of human delusions, if not for one "but". The world is not ultimately ruled by politicians, because they do not invent ideas. The world is ruled by those who invent ideas that will eventually be implemented by politicians.

Vindana Shiva did not just successfully speak from the high western stands, where all this organic farming is very much in vogue. She became one of the main thinkers who influenced the formation of ideas in the mind of Gotabai Rajapaksa.

This democratically elected president of Sri Lanka, during his election campaign, actively promoted the idea of ​​​​transition to organic farming and the abandonment of fertilizers, just in the spirit of Shiva's famous statements that fertilizers should not have been allowed for use in agriculture at all. And, of course, she was an adviser to the Sri Lankan state in this matter.
So, the thinker once again seized into intellectual slavery another, in the words of Keynes, a man of practice who considers himself completely unaffected by intellectual influences. What came of it?
The fate of manure in a tropical climate

In April 2021, the government of Sri Lanka materialized Vindana Shiva's theses on the ban on fertilizers and pesticides: their import into the country was banned. By the way, one of the reasons was the need to save foreign currency, for which all this was bought. Fertilizers and pesticides did cost a couple of hundred million dollars a year.

The first agricultural season of 2021 (there are two of them a year on the island) was not affected by the “organic green transition”: fertilizers and pesticides from warehouses closed the issue. The problems started in the second season:
The climate on the island is quite equatorial, which is why the problem of weeds is very acute / © Wikimedia Commons

“It is more than clear that this 2021/2022 season's rice harvest will be 40-45% below average. The main reason is the transition from synthetic to organic fertilizers...forced by politicians through directives. It was predictable - it is enough to know how organic fertilizers affect crops, as well as the fate of organic fertilizers in tropical conditions, ”
- writes a representative of the local agricultural industry.

So it is, about organic fertilizers, he is absolutely right. Any hot climate makes long-term storage and transportation of manure a full-fledged ancient adventure on Homeric scales. The ideologues of organic farming usually miss this point: it is assumed that agriculture should consist of small farms, where the farmer collects manure from his own cattle, and therefore there are no problems of transportation and storage at all.

However, the economic reality is that, in most cases, breaking even agriculture requires specialization in either pastoralism or arable farming—and Sri Lanka is expected to be dominated by the latter. Therefore, manure is scarce here.

Importing it from other countries, even if we do not talk about the deadly smell and rapid decay during such transportation in the heat, is expensive. Because the main part of the manure is not the nitrogen, potassium and the like that plants need, but rotting organic residues from carbon and hydrogen. Simply put, to replace 1 ton of mineral fertilizers, you will have to import many tons of manure - or lower yields.
It is expensive to import many tons of manure, so in the end, the agriculture of the former Ceylon went the second way.

The result was predictable: rice prices on the island rose by 50%. From a crop failure, he turned from a rice exporter into an importer - rice had to be imported for $ 450 million, more than twice as much as spending on fertilizer imports. The country's foreign exchange balance received a double blow: exports fell, as rice fell out of exports, and imports rose, since all the same rice now has to be imported.

Maybe only the rice was damaged? No: last season's corn harvest was 50,000 tons, and this year they predict... 60 tons (yes, that's not a typo, almost a thousand times less). Well, what's the point of planting corn if its reduced yield will make the cost of such an "organic crop" higher than market prices? The need for corn has not gone away: now it just has to be imported.

Lost revenues from tea exports in the last three months of 2020 alone amount to $25 million. The total harm to the Sri Lankan tea industry is $425 million. Yields of other important local export crops — coconut palm and hevea (rubber) — also fell by tens of percent.

The catastrophe became so obvious that in November 2021, Rajapaksa finally gave in and reversed the decision to ban the import of fertilizers and pesticides. So far, only in relation to export crops: the inflow of foreign currency into the country was especially acutely dependent on them.

Alas, it was too late: the struggle of the Europeans with long-term contracts with Gazprom raised the price of gas in Europe, and then around the world. And the cost of fertilizers, even before the rise in gas prices by 80%, was formed by him.

When fertilizers were allowed to be sold again, a black market had already formed for them, with inflated prices typical of it. Sri Lankan farmers are protesting against this ugly phenomenon, but no one has yet been able to curb it. Despite the hot climate, everyone is wearing masks: in this sense, Sri Lanka is definitely ahead of Russia / © Wikimedia Commons
As a result, buying fertilizers at the new prices turned out to be unaffordable for local agriculture, which was badly affected by the drop in yields “according to the organic scenario”.

Now there is a crisis in Sri Lanka: the government, apparently, will change, the country has declared a default, there is not enough currency to buy energy resources that have risen in price around the world, which is why electricity has been turned off on the island since the end of March.

The islanders, who have never seen such a thing almost never, protest. But this situation cannot be rectified quickly: fertilizers and pesticides are much more expensive this year than in the past. And farmers have never had enough money to buy them, because a year without a harvest has knocked the ground out from under their feet.
Is “organic farming” capable of feeding anyone normally?

Organic farming is of three types. The first is "California". Farmers grow everything on manure and without pesticides, as a result they invest a lot of manual labor in weeding and have yields 20-30% lower than those who apply mineral fertilizers and pesticides.

The price of their products is at least tens of percent higher than in the supermarket. But their customers are people with complex ideas in their heads and therefore pay higher prices with the same ease with which Mavrodi's clients gave money to MMM in the 1990s. This model is stable: there are enough wealthy people with specific ideas in developed countries.

The second type of "organic farming" is in the poorest parts of Africa: the locals simply don't have the money for fertilizers and pesticides. They live mainly on subsistence farming and starve in case of crop failure, since they also do not have cash reserves to buy food on the market.

The third, local variety of "organic farming" is the "Ovsyannikov variant", no-till farming in the form in which it was invented by a Russian agronomist at the end of the 19th century. It is practiced, for example, in the Penza region. Fertilizers are not normally applied here (and even manure), but the yield is decent, since tractors plow everything except the harvested grain back into the ground with special agricultural implements. In the “hay-straw” land, after harvesting, the wheat rots, providing the next year with a normal level of nitrogen and phosphorus in the soil.

The problem of “how to deal with weeds without herbicides” is also solved by machines, and not by “chemistry”: the weeds are allowed to germinate first in the spring, and then the tractors pass, grind them, plowing the remains into the ground (a kind of “green manure”). Wheat is already sown on top of such processing.

This scheme works, but it has a huge drawback, because of which the theorists of organic farming will never be satisfied with it: it does not solve problems "in a natural way", but by the optimal use of mechanized tillage.

Meanwhile, all theorists of organic farming require maximum "naturalness" from it. This may be one of the reasons why the Ovsyannikov scheme is not used in the Western world (there is no-till farming in the West, but it is completely different, still with fertilizers).

The Ceylonese do not live in Russia, they have a different climate and basic cultures, and they have no information about Ovsyannikov's methods. So, in theory, they could maintain their yields in only one way: to import several times more manure to the island than they previously imported mineral fertilizers, and also to sharply increase the investment of labor in their agriculture.

Because the cultivation of tea bushes is not wheat in the Penza region. Walking across the field with a tractor, chopping all the weeds with a special tool and plowing them, will not work. And weeds in a warm and humid climate grow very intensively - as, in fact, cultivated plants. So they would have to be weeded out by hand, attracting a lot more people than before. Well, or enjoying the drop in yield. Sri Lanka, August 3, 2021, manual weeding of a tea plantation. Usually the tea bushes are too close together for high efficiency mechanized weeding: there is a high chance of damaging the roots / ©ISHARA S. KODIKARA/AFP via Getty Images
Sri Lanka has only a couple of million farmers, less than 10% of the population. Therefore, the island spontaneously took the second path, and not at all the first.

By the way: Vindana Shiva, although he does not offer to solve the problem of weeds other than by hand, offers an "organic" means of controlling insect pests. This, attention, is the oil of the Indian neem tree.

Well, it's a really good insecticide... only it, like all biopesticides, is much more expensive than chemical ones. And, of course, the Sri Lankans could not use it, because the oil is too expensive for farmers with incomes below California.
Lessons: Still Not Learned

In fact, the main lesson of the Sri Lankan crisis is not at all the fallacy of the ideas of organic farming. It was obvious even before that: it was well known from the experience of developed countries that the costs of "organic" farmers are higher, and their yields are lower.

The main lesson from Sri Lanka is the pointlessness of the “cancellation culture” in relation to the ideas of technological progress. Since the 1960s, since Rachel Carson's crusade against pesticides and a similar anti-nuclear crusade, ideas have been spreading around the world about the harmfulness and harmfulness of key technologies used by modern man.

If before the 1960s people saw progress as a means of increasing prosperity and the basis of the success of our species, after that they increasingly see it as a source of evil. "Sustainable" is now called such systems of management, which minimally use energy and substances from anthropogenic sources. The sun should shine over the field and it should rain - and that's it.

This is a false concept. The use of technology, synthesized fertilizers and pesticides appeared for a reason, but because it allowed us to get much more food from the same area of ​​​​land than any organic farming can do.

Brown shows the area under cereals in the world. It is easy to see that they have changed little for more than half a century. Green shows those lands that the increase in productivity, which has happened since the Green Revolution, allows not to use / ©OurWorldInData

The same can be said about other harsh accusations against progress from the same Vindana Shiva and her associates. Speaking of the "climate crisis", she forgets to clarify that the anthropogenic emissions of carbon dioxide that gave rise to it led the terrestrial vegetation to the most prosperous state in the last 50 thousand years at least. Speaking about the perniciousness of fertilizers, Shiva forgets that no modern country has been able to solve the food problem without them.

The key lesson from Sri Lanka is that we need to stop thinking as idiots those who have created technological progress, because of which we have been using less and less land for 30 years, but in the end we have the least hunger in the history of the human species.

Still, Ukraine, with all its madness, is very much needed by Russia as an example of how not to live. For example, one cannot use vaccination just for the sake of vaccination and lining the pockets of oligarchs and officials. It was this fascinating activity that caused the first open anti-vaccination parental rebellion in Europe, which the WHO, the Supreme Court, the media, the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Education of Ukraine cannot suppress now. After the work of Canadian Uliana Suprun, who fled the country, and the mass deaths of children from poor-quality vaccines, people refuse to believe them and are more likely to pay for a fake certificate than to play the lottery with the health and life of a child.

The last to attack Ukrainian parents was the Supreme Court of Ukraine, which recently ruled that an unvaccinated child should not attend kindergarten. This is stated in the decision of the court dated April 17, 2019. He did not satisfy the claim of the mother, who defended her right to take her child to a preschool educational institution without mandatory vaccinations. It should be noted that back in June 2016, a Ukrainian woman filed a lawsuit demanding not to interfere with her unvaccinated child in receiving preschool education. At first, her claim was satisfied by the decision of the Slavuta District Court of the Khmelnytsky region. However, in 2017, the preschool educational institution filed an appeal, which was granted. But the decision of the court of first instance was canceled, and a new decision was made, which denied the claim. We add that the Supreme Court decided that the individual interest of a person (refusing to be vaccinated) cannot be placed above the general interest of society - not to get sick with infectious diseases. The court ruling stated that "the task of the state is to ensure that the optimal balance is maintained between the realization of the child's right to preschool education and the interests of other children."

This was the first official victory of officials over their parents. Earlier, in September 2018, the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine sent an official letter to the heads of all regional state administrations, in which they decided not to allow unvaccinated children to enter educational institutions. Now this rule has been fixed by the court. The Ukrainians themselves told RIA Katyusha that they are now waiting for a sharp rise in the price of fake vaccination certificates from about a thousand rubles for our money to one and a half to two thousand. According to the inhabitants of the country, this is not the highest price for the life of their child.

You can understand officials and judges - they simply have nowhere to go: in connection with the measles epidemic, which began to spread across Europe from Ukraine, everyone is putting pressure on them - WHO, UNICEF, the European Union. Western "partners" openly demand to bring the vaccination rate from the African level to at least some decent indicators. Today Ukraine is on a par with Romania and Albania.

It would seem, what is the question, it is necessary to cure everyone, instill and there will be happiness. However, then the department of a Canadian citizen with a diploma of a paramedic, an activist of the Maidan, the former head of the Ministry of Health, Uliana Suprun, who has now fled from Ukraine, enters the matter. In fact, her role in the current anti-vaccination riot is difficult to overestimate. Having carried out the most serious work on the collapse of medical care, district hospitals and ambulances as such, she and her team actively took up vaccination and received an epidemic of complications after vaccinations against polio, after which even doctors rebelled against vaccination. “The Government of Canada provided 3 million Canadian dollars as a humanitarian aid for the purchase of OPV and IPV (polio vaccine) by the UNICEF Children's Fund. The total procurement includes 1.1 million doses of IPV vaccine and 3.7 million doses of OPV vaccine. On June 26 (2014), the Ministry of Health of Ukraine announced that the first batch of vaccines was received in the amount of 1.5 million doses of OPV and 600,000 doses of IPV.

According to the preventive vaccination calendar, in Ukraine, vaccination of children for the prevention of poliomyelitis is carried out at the age of 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 18 months, 6 years and 14 years. The OPV vaccine is used for the 3rd to 6th vaccination (at 6 months, 18 months, 6 years and 14 years of age) in the absence of contraindications to OPV. The annual need for OPV vaccine is about 2 million doses. Given the need for such a volume and humanitarian aid in the amount of 1.5 million doses, continuous vaccination can be carried out for 9 months ... At the same time, the vaccine arrived in Ukraine in a thawed form: the temperature regime during the transportation of the vaccine was observed in the range from 2 to 8 ° C , which is allowed by the instructions of the drug. But. Such storage conditions significantly reduce the shelf life (up to 6 months from the date of defrosting!) and increase the risk of not using the vaccine, instead of the possibility of using the vaccine for 2 years when stored in a refrigerator in frozen form (-20 ° C). UNICEF deliberately supplied the drug after defrosting, which obliges us to promptly use the OPV vaccine to vaccinate the country's population in the near future. After receiving the humanitarian cargo, the next day, May 22, the State Enterprise "Ukrvaktsyna" writes a letter to the Deputy Minister of Health Peregynets I.B. with a request to clarify the regime for the subsequent storage of vaccines. The letter informs that the goods were accepted for storage at the warehouse on May 21, and focuses on the transportation of the vaccine at a temperature of 2-8 °C. As a result of the change in the cold chain, the state-owned enterprise also confirms changes in the expiration dates, which have been reduced to 6 months from the date of production, and the inability to refreeze the vaccine if it has already been thawed. The apogee of history was the resolution on May 29 by Deputy Minister Igor Peregynets, who single-handedly decides to re-freeze the vaccine to -20 ° C according to UNICEF recommendations, contrary to the instructions for the drug. Perhaps the responsible persons of the Ministry of Health or UNICEF relied on the OPV instructions from other manufacturers, where several “defrost-freeze” cycles are allowed. But for the OPVERO vaccine, this is prohibited! The decision of the Deputy Minister was, of course, carried out. 1.5 million doses of the OPV vaccine were re-frozen,” the Medical Control portal tells this sentimental story.

It would seem that the most reasonable thing to do after that was to simply throw away the spoiled vaccines and not risk it, but no - how could Ukraine throw away so much valuable humanitarian cargo? The vaccine was re-thawed, injected into children. The result was not long in coming. Here are just a few cases from the list of Ukrainian media:

On November 3, 2015, Kolya Antonyuk, aged 5.5, died. Symptoms of an intestinal viral infection: abdominal pain, high fever. According to available information, he was vaccinated against polio on October 29th. Vinnitsa. Girl, 4 years old. I was vaccinated against poliomyelitis in the Sabarovsk kindergarten. Hospitalized with symptoms of a viral infection (high temperature). She died on the same day. The information was received on November 25, 2015.

Belaya Tserkov, November 25, 2015, boy, 3.5 years old. He was vaccinated at the beginning of the month, hospitalized with symptoms of an intestinal viral infection (high fever, abdominal pain, nausea). Received a course of antibiotic therapy. He died suddenly a few days after discharge. There is information about the falsification of medical records.
